snippet: The number of Americans who cannot vote because they have been convicted of a felony continues to grow. These limits are seriously counterproductive.
abstract: Editorial holds that laws barring felons from voting are counterproductive, especially in the case of ex-convicts who have fully served their sentences and returned to society; notes that such laws are particularly discriminatory in the case of blacks, of whom 7.7 percent are disenfranchised because of criminal records.
lead_paragraph: The number of Americans who cannot vote because they have been convicted of a felony continues to grow. These limits are seriously counterproductive.
